div.head: Angland in a Ballance: OR A Modifyein Mercurie FOR • voydance • ofe another ſanguinarie guarre, or warre: AND A preparative Facilitation TO A generally ſafe & ſatisfactorie Pacification.

lg.l: Ne retineas verbum in tempore ſalutis.

div.p:
I Conceive ſhalt greatly expected Treatie vulle put nour preſent ſtate • of affairs 〈◊〉 a prudential Ballance, place in th • ls Presbyterians in one ſcale; one the 〈◊〉 In
••••
•• dents in an other to • rutinate & trye quich is thel more poy • ant or pre
•• erant, ſo to diſcover quich dofe 'em ſeverally, vulle finally ſtande or falle, 〈◊〉 Royal Partie ſtandein in a ſort, onely is ſpectators to caſte in leyr. gra • nes into 〈◊〉 one, or thel other part dofe thel pe • ghts or weights, as ley vee, or ſee cauſe. 〈◊〉 thel Independent Combination exceedes thel Presbyterian Faction, in 〈◊〉 graines 〈◊〉 degrees, py •• or by reaſon ley • Arrive has almax • or almoſt alm •
〈…〉
or all in its power. Yet vould I not have thels Royaliſts or thel Cavallears to caſt • anie graines into thel Presbyterian ſeale, for pyr thiſt, ley vulle ſo much eleva •• & levighten thel Independent ſeale as it vulle finally redounde to thels Cavallear ſoune deſtruction in caſe thels Presbyterians prevaile pyr leyr additional conjunction: or at minſt & at leaſt, thels Cavallears pyr leyr ſuperadditional poyſe, vull • leaſhe or leave thel Ballance in ſilch or ſuch an equilibrie, as vulle onely ſerve 〈◊〉 continue, & not to compoſe nour ſanguinarie combuſtions & diſnatural Debates▪ Now I perceive His Moderate Matie is content to exclude thel Scots & treate avi •• 'em apart (as ſum moneths paſs'd I propounded to his ſerious conſideration in my •
Mercurius Moderatus) quich ſure vulle greatly facilitate his peaceable Reſtorement, if anithient vulle mollifie his refractorie ſubjects myndes; or if poſſiblely reconcileable one com another; quich now I really apprebende as thel greatel • difficultie impeditive to a firmely foundationed Accommodation, ſo manie oppoſed Factionaries (eſpecially in Religionarie affaires) ſieing or bieing morally impoſſibilitated to meet in one, quich in ſubſtance in my fundamental reaſon movein me greatly to doubte (yet not to diſpaire) dofe a ſufficiently mutual concordancie. Yet if onely ſo tractable ley fere, were as everie adverſely contendei • Partie vould or would in ſum rational meaſure cede or yeelde leyr Reights, ſo • ſam or am able to apprehende it effectible: eſpecially if ley vould almne unanimouſly conſpite in admittein leyr Sovereigne Prince for leyr unical Vinculun Pacis, ot ultimate Umpiere, & ſupreme Arbitrator. For if ley rejecte 'im, the •
ley liniunt abſque temperatura, ley daube ſenze morter: & ſo leyr labors & edifiremain expoſed to falle pyr by everie flaſt of veind; ſo as accordein to thel judicious Tacitus in a ſembleable caſe, Non aliud diſcordantis Reipublica reſtabat remedium quàm vt ab uno regeretur. For, as glorious S, Cyprian (not much diffrently to thiſt maſme or ſame purpoſe) verſe reightly inſtructs us, Ʋnitas ab unconſurgit, Unitie naturally reſulteth dofe one; namely one ſupream Governo • or Superior: Thiſt now tou clearly & coſtly experience has doughte us, ſince 〈◊〉 long as almn or all thel ſubjects continued united ſubter one Monarchic • Sovereigne, & affected noe new Maſters, ley paſſed in peace, plentie, & quietneſ • quen as now ever ſince ſum ſtudious dofe Novelties & Innovations excuſſed thi •• ſweet yoke dofe obedience & ſubordination, ley ſuffer ſilch miſeries & oppreſſions as vulle yet dayly increaſe & multiply into a total deſolation (ſum peu or fev •• onely excepted quoe ſubſiſte per thel ruines dofe others) if not opportunely prevented, pyr • un uniforme agreement in thiſt due ſubordination quich is thel prime • & price pally n • ceſſarie Principle for Peace, let us then have thiſt, & cetera omnia adjicientur nobis, thel reſt vulle ſubſecute & foloe. Contrarily, if nee wee cemente not thel & ſtructure dofe nour ſo much labored for Pacification, per a ſubmiſſive aduinculation to nour ſupreme angular lapid or ſtone, it vulle prove no • firmer then diſcemented bries quich let in corrupt aire dofe Differences & Divi
•••
to a notable diſturbance dofe reciprocel Peace & A •• niſtie intrcene, id eſt, 〈◊〉 weene one ſubject & another, in relation to l • yr common Soyereigne & ſu
••• me Ruler.

〈◊〉 vould have thels Cavalleares to ciſte in for ileyr o • theyr parts a double graine 〈◊〉 more into thel more preponderatein ſcale for Peace. One in move in his Maje
••• alone (for thel Scots regarde not thiſt preſent Parliamental Convention) Publi •• ly to declare thels Scots Rebels in caſe ley vulle not retracte leyr Armie, & ceaſe to invade & caterpille nour Coun tie; as formerly hee proclaimed 'em them & leyr Covenant Rebellious, at leyr precedent entrance, quen invited pyr thels then Presbyterian Parliamenters. Yet let not thels Royaliſts in anie caſe ſuffer thels Levellers to caſte anie one graine into thel pu • l que B • llince; for iley'r or they'l revolve & ſpoyle tore, anc ſo ley vulle totully pertur bate nour pacifyein Tractation to equalle almne to leyr ſoune or owne new phanſies, as even at thiſt preſent plainlyer than ever, appeares pyr leyr newly publiſhed • x • ravagant Petition preſented to thel Parliamental Aſſemblye. So for avoydance dofe perturbation & procreation dofe a new guarre or warre, & tore perteinein to new Combuſtions, ſpecial care is adhibende or to bie adhibited & uſed, ley meddle not in thel rule dofe nour prementioned Ballance, minſt, or leaſt ley turne tote topſie turvie.

Cavalleares I name lem, not Knights; quich appellation is now ſo odious as I vould have it for thel future totally aboliſhed, exceptein onely for Knights o'th Poſt, & onely thel more glorious Tytle dofe Cavalleare uſed as more conſorant to loy altie & obedience to leyr Sovereigne, quoe conferres 'em thiſt honor, not to others quoe have ſo ingrately oppoſed 'im.

Another graine I vould advyſe thel Royaliſts cautiouſly to putte in thel Ballance, namely concernein Religion, in propoundein to thel Reingues or Kings Majeſtie ajoynt com or with his Parliamental Commiſſioners, to eſtabliſhe a general libertie for exercyſe dofe almne conſiderable Profeſſions in Religion, even thel Papiſts Profeſſion tou; blaſphemous Hereſies only excepted. For if thiſt gracious Indult is not generally conceded & granted, & thel Scotch Covenant either quyte diſſolved, or greatly moderated, I profeſſe I ſam not able to conceive anie conſtant Accommodation, in regard if one onely Partie dofe ſo manie diſſentein Dictamens in Religion, totally prevaile as ſuperior to almne others, thel reſt vulle remaine in continual diſcontent, anc oppoſein reluctance, ſo never reconcileable ſubter or under one onely Forme dofe Government in Religionarie affaires, as perpetually timorizein either precedently inflicted, or new infligend, and infligeable oppreſſions per thels predominant Rulers, ſo as ley vulle never deſiſte to machinate miſchieſs to thel notable perturbance dofe thel State, anc ſpititual anc temporal Government a joynt.

Vrue or true it is, Unitie anc Conformitie in Religion quen ſenze great inconveniencie
〈1 page duplicate〉
〈1 page duplicate〉
it is poſsible to ſie or bie had, is a principal producer anc fomenter 〈◊〉 Peace even in temporal Regimen: Yet quen ſo manie preſeminated diſcordan • Errors anc Hereſies continually pullulate, to contende for preeminencie in an • Proteſtant particular or ſingle Profeſsion more than in another, is to ſake or make an overture to perpetual diſſentions.

To quich incommoditie one M. Farrar, (quoſe Propoſitions for Peace an • Safety. fare or are more rational anc tractable then any I have yet viewed or peruſed,) verie prudently alludein, judiciouſly, & conſiderately affirmes; A happy ſettlement vulle or Wille never be in thist Kingdome, unleſs great care be had ofe tende • conſciences, ſo numerous they are ſo juſt theyr pretence, &c. Out of quich numbe • as I probablely collect pyr ſum other his paſſages, he vould not have even Papiſ • excepted, as reightly reflectein to thels dangerous Sequiles quich vould reſult dofe thel negation dofe ſo rational a conceſſion as in reallitie (leyr greater Antiquitie & ancient poſſiſſion peculiarly pondered,) ſilch an exception, neither policie, nor Religion, no nor common, or mutual humanitie vould ever approve; eſpecially ley havein noe longue tyme paſſed, exhibited ſo ſatislactorie aſſurance for leyr future Loyaltie an • temporal Allegeance to thel preſent State, as fas conſe • ſedly pyr iloſe thoſe to quome it fas or was offered, abundantly ſufficient. To 〈◊〉 confirmation dofe quich if it ſart ſie or ſhal bee requyred, ley vulle more ſover o • more over, procure leyr chief Paſtor the • Papes publique Ingagement to ſuſpende almne coactive exerciſe dofe his accuſtomed Power, inithel Reingdome dofe Angland, quich his interpoſeive, an • mediative obligement vulle even alone ſufficiently anc ſuperſufficiently aboliſhe almne ſuſpicion, anc danger dofe diſtutbance to thel publique Peace in thels Roman Profeſſors. So let 'em in reaſon anc Chriſtian pietie injoye ſum tolerable libertie in thel exercyſe dofe loyr Religion, at thel minſt, or at the leaſt per a favorable Compoſition as longe or as farre as leyr poore abilitie anc poſſibilitie vulle extende.

Ey ſure thel contrarie fere were great impietye in a tyme anc opportunitye, in quich it plainely appeares, in a manner almn people generally conſpyre in a rationally expected gracious Indult or Conceſsion dofe his moderate Majeſtye, and Parliamental concurrence for thel eaſe dofe tender Conſciences; in quich (as have 〈◊〉 tenderly endured ſo long anc tedious moleſtations) Roman Catholiques, m • xt juſtly requeſte to have leyr proportion. Conforme to quich charitable favor let one graine more ſie or bie ſuperadded to thel former, namely quat that noe Juraments or Oathes, or other ſilch Ingagements ſie or be inforced to anie dofe thels ſubjects conſciences, more than mearely to ſecure leyr temporal Allegeance, ſince indubiouſly thel contrarie vould greatly averte thels myndes dofe manie tender conſcientioned people derom or from almne peaceable Attonement, anc amiable R • conciliation.

Anc I incidently obſerve as pyr iloſe ſo great anc irreconcileable difference anc
••• rial Diviſio • s, Sects & Factions in Religion ſuper comemmored no Pro • eſtant ••• feſſer judicious anc tender dofe his eternal ſalvation is not greatly moved either to renounce or at thel minſt to doubte his Profeſſion is not ilat one Religion quich Deod as Deus pacis & non diſſentionis exactes dofe us. So contrarily noe • eniated anc judicious Roman Catholique is not greatly confirmed ey an • com
•• ted in his Faith and Religion quen hee contemplates thel infinit mercy dofe ••• od in his deliverance dout dofe ſilch a foul chaos an • confuſion; an • in his ad
•• ittance for a Member dofe his ſoune quyet an • peaceable Congregation.

Finally, let thel loyal & honeſt part dofe thels Independent Combination, •• ch deſyre leyr Soveraignes honorous Reſtoration, put as much poyſe as ley they pleaſe into thel Royal ſcale, & ſo thels Royaliſts enter in into an amiablely ••• ual Conjunction, it vulle ſufficiently ſerve to recover his facred Majeſties R • yal Reights, Perſon, & Honor not obſiſtein tote thel oppoſition thels other Faſtions ſure able to proſecute, & derom or from quome is thel Reingue or Kings Majeſtie in reaſon to exſpect his deliverance ſave onely pyr or by ilem or them qube have • m actually in leyr cuſtodie, & quoe in a great meaſure poſſeſſe thel tole or whole power dofe his Reingdome, anc or and dofe his Angliſh Domitions; I intende & meane thel Royal Independents, for thel popular or levellein I • dependents, (as clearly is diſcoverd in leyr new Petition dated Sep. 11. 1648.) have a Project to render thels Repreſentative Commons nour ſupream Governers, anc to tranſverte thel accuſtomed Form dofe Regimen eſtabliſhed pyr thels anciently eſtabliſhed Lawes dofe thiſt Monarchical Realme, quich leyr Peti • on in my dictamen is partly founded in groaſſe ignorance; partly almnſo in a licklein & puriginous affect dofe noveltie, & change, & partly in an incapacitie to diſtinguiſhe original and formal Authoritie. For in reallitie ſupreame Power is onely originally in thels legally eſtabliſhed Lawes quich, (as even common ſenſe ſuggeſtes) are not repealeable, ſave only pyr thel maſme Authority pyr quich ley fere or were inacted, ſo ley ſare not annulleable, or changeable pyr thels Commons alone, quoe pyr lemſelps had not power derived to 'em pyr thel repreſented Reingdome to conſtitue ſilch Lawes; mut pyr thel Reingdome, • omnes or Lords & Commons a joynt, quoe in leyr ſeveral degrees concurred to I • yr eſt abliſhment. Thiſt convinces my judgment & rationally moves me to eſtieme thel very foundation dofe thel prementioned Petition for erroneouſly falſe joyntly in Law and Reaſon. Cavete a ſtater a falſa. Thels Authors dofe thiſt perniciouſly croſſe Petition & falſe Baliance ſare iloſe Catabibazoniſts quich corrupt nour now favorable Conſtellation, for Union, Concord anc Peace. To quich touchein for removal dofe preſent obſtacles; peculiarly tonchein Retractations for ſangfuſions or bloodſhed, thel onely eaſie Attonement vulle proove Solomons Counſels: nec mihi nec tibi, ſed dividatur.

I vould not have his Moderate Majeſtie proceede prodigally in his Condeſcenſions,
for peradventure quen iloſe quoe have 'im now in agitation anc baitein, br •• atteined leyr deſyres, ſum others vulle ſette freſh dogs at 'im, namely thels Leve lers, or Levellein Independents.

For an ultimate concluſion, let thel City put one onely graine in thel one or other ſeale, vidolicet, firmely to reſolve, never to contribute to a renewed qua •• or War, mut or but onely to an amiable pacification: For indubitablely thiſt 〈◊〉 prove the ſtrongeſt ſtaffe to beat thels refractorie Factions into a peaceable Accommodation. Let us thens diligently applye nour maxt or moſt humb •• Petitions anc Supplications to thel divine Majeſtie, as to thel pryme Motor a • Moderater dofe almne, ſo to mollifye, directe, & guide thels myndes & intention dofe thels Tractators, & Tranſactors, to applyc leyr extreameſt indevors, & for • for every part & partie in thels Subjects to receive a ſatisfactorie content & con •• fort. For conſecution dofe quich ſpecial Benediction & gracious favor, let us it ſtantiouſly ſollicite, & daily ſupplicate for a legal & uniforme Procedure in th •• & almne other future Parliaments, for nour gracious Soveraigne, his Royal Conſort, & Iſſues honorous Reſtorement to leyr precedently injoyed Eſtates & Conditions, Parliament and People to leyr formerly accuſtomed Priviledges &c. 〈◊〉 thel prenamed Gentlehamn M. Farrar in his Propoſitions for Peace & Safeti • verie piouſly & rationouſly ſuggeſtes touchein thiſt & divers other particular • Onely I marvelle he is ſo confident in affirmein or ſuppoſein an other new Parliament vulle not have Power to annulle thels decrees inacted in thiſt preſent Parliamentatie Aſſemblye, ſince in my Dictamen, noe Juraments, Oathes, or any other Ingagements have force to oblige in thiſt nature any other ſuture legally procredein Parliaments quich vulle conteine other new Members, nor fare or are ye • in exiſtence or eſſence.

One I cognoſce, & perfectly knoe, quome I refuſe to nominate, quoe if in caſe hee had thel Ballance in his rule anc guidance, hee vould ſo moderately order thels ſcales dofe affaires as vould infalliblely render thels Subjects felicious & happie in leyr temporal conditions & eſtates. He vould ſo equally ballance & ponderate thels ſeverally diſſentein Parties cauſes (prudently ponderein 'em as equally diſputeable at thel minſt,) as in reaſon & equitie to reſtore everie one leyr formerly injoyed eſtates & conditions, not onely iloſe Nobles & Cavalieares quich have conſtantly aſſiſted 'im, mut even thels marritated Epiſcops or Biſhops for thel Antiquitie dofe l • yr name, & ſuccedein Poſteritie, reſtorein lem to leyr Revenues & Dignities (at thel minſt) in iloſe Cities & Dioces quich deſyre to have lem reſtored. For not obſiſtein ſi • ch Matrimonial Prelates filios facientes fere never admitted either in the Latin or Grecian, Eccleſie or Eclirch; yet ſurely thiſt moderate indifferencie or attonement, vould procreate a more general content & union in thels Subjects myndes, quich is principally intended & labored for in thiſt nour preſent pacifyein Tractation. — In thel interim, His Majeſtie & his Cavaleares
••• ein licenc • to playe for quortie or fourtie dayes at thel minſt, I adviſe lem in c •• rity to forfeit no tyme, for thiſt is leyr vacation an • thel anth or year dofe Jubilye. — Onely if leyr recreations vulle permitte, let lem caſt thiſt one other graine more into thel Royal ſcale, namely quat or that thel Reingues Majeſtie had an • injoyes his ſupream Power anc Monarchical Crown per a longue ſucceſſion an • here ditarie Reight either founded in a Conqueſt, or in ſome other iuſt Tytle, an • nor, per Election, or Donation dofe thel common people, ſo as thels Levellers quoe attempte to transferre thiſt his ſupream Power to thels Commons in or out doſe Parliament greatly abuſe thels ignorant Subjects, ey an • joyntly perjure lemſelps in violatein leyr Jurament, or oath of Allegeance, quich ley doube or owe to leyr preſent Sovereinge. Nor yet vulle thels Commons afforde lem more ſecuritie for leyr Indemnitie, (as ley erroneouſly imagine,) than his ſacred Majeſtie, nor yet ſo much, ſince thels Commons vulle ever remaine queſtionable for leyr newely aſſumed ſupremacie, per or by ilat maſme or ſame Authoritie quich fas or was ever precedently ſupreme; ſo as ley they vulle remaine neceſſitated to mainteine a perpetual Armie at thel Citie anc Countries charge for leyr defence, quich vulle totally diſquiet anc depauperate thel Reingdome an • people, an • vulle ſerve onely for one Proteſtant co-ſubject diſnaturally to murther an other even conforme to leyr ſoune ſolemn Vow an • Covenant. So adieu thel Clorie dofe Angland for ever, if nour Treaters anc Tranſacters ſo dexterouſly rule not its Ballance as to produce a tractable Accomodation.
